stk.molecular.topologies.base module¶

Defines the base Topology type.

Extending stk: Adding new topologies.¶

General¶

A new topology class must be defined. The class must inherit Topology. The new topology class will have to define the methods place_mols() and bonded_fgs(). A description of what these methods should do is given by Topology.place_mols() and Topology.bonded_fgs().

The new class may optionally define the methods prepare() and cleanup(). The former perfroms operations on the molecule before it is joined up and has atoms deleted via react(). The latter any final cleanup operations on the assembled molecule. For example, converting the end functional groups of a polymer into hydrogen atoms. See also Topology.cleanup().

Cages¶

To add a new cage topology a new class should be created, named after the topology. This class should inherit CageTopology. This will give access to various methods which are necessary for dealing with any cage molecule. See the documenation of CageTopology for more details.

The new class will only need to have five class attributes added:

  1. a list called vertices
  2. a list called edges
  3. n_windows, which holds the number of windows the cage topology has.
  4. n_window_types, which holds the number of different window types. For example, if n_window_types is 2, then the topology will have two kinds of windows, each with a different expected size. Windows of the same type are expected to be of the same size.

vertices holds instances of Vertex. Each instance represents a vertex of a cage and needs to be initialized with the coordinates of that vertex. Vertices of a cage are where building blocks of cages are placed.

edges holds instances of the Edge. Each instance represents an edge of a cage and needs to be initialized with two instances of Vertex. The Vertex instances should be held in vertices, as mentioned above. The two vertices are the ones which the edge connects. Linkers of cages are placed on edges. The edge instances automatically derive their positions from the vertices supplied during initialization.

The vertices need to be positioned such that the center of the topology is at the origin.

class stk.molecular.topologies.base.Linear(repeating_unit, orientation, n, ends='h')¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.base.Topology

A class represting linear polymers.

repeating_unit¶

str – A string showing the repeating unit of the Polymer. For example, "AB" or "ABB". The building block with index 0 in MacroMolecule.building_blocks is labelled as "A" while index 1 as "B" and so on.

orientation¶

tuple of float – For each character in the repeating unit, a value between 0 and 1 (both inclusive) must be given in a list. It indicates the probability that each monomer will have its orientation along the chain flipped.

n¶

int – The number of repeating units which are used to make the polymer.

ends¶

str – The string represents how the end groups of the polymer are treated. If 'h' the functional groups at the end of the polymer are converted into hydrogem atoms. If 'fg' they are kept as the original functional group.

_x_position(macro_mol, bb)¶

Calculates the x coordinate on which to place bb.

Does this by checking the most how for down the x axis macro_mol stretches and checking the distance between the minimum x position of bb and its centroid. It then tries to place bb about 3 A away from macro_mol.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
  • bb (StructUnit) – The building block to be added to macro_mol.
Returns:

The x coordinate on which to place bb.
Return type:

float
bonded_fgs(macro_mol)¶

Yields functional groups to react.

Parameters:macro_mol (Polymer) – The polymer being assembled.
Yields:tuple of int – Holds the ids of the functional groups set to react.
cleanup(macro_mol)¶

Deletes the atoms which are lost during assembly.

Parameters:macro_mol (Polymer) – The polymer being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
hygrogen_ends(macro_mol)¶

Removes all atoms tagged for deletion and adds hydrogens.

In polymers, you want to replace the functional groups at the ends with hydrogen atoms.

Parameters:macro_mol (Polymer) – The polymer being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
place_mols(macro_mol)¶

Places monomers side by side.

The monomers are placed along the x-axis, so that the vector running between the functional groups is placed along the axis. Functional groups are tagged with 'fg_id' such that 'fg_id' increases along the x-axis.

Parameters:macro_mol (Polymer) – The polymer being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
class stk.molecular.topologies.base.Topology(react_del=True)¶

Bases: object

Builds macromolecules.

More accurately, child classes of Topology take care of building macromolecules.

This class directly defines any operations and attributes that are needed by any topology during assembly. However, this class is not used directly. It is intended to be inherited from. All MacroMolecule.topology attributes hold an instance of a Topology child class. Child classes of Topology define operations specific to that one topology. For example, each child class must define a join_mols(), which creates bonds between the building blocks of a macromolecule. The way in which this is done will depend on what kind of macromolecules are being built. In addition, each child class must define methods which place the building blocks in approriate positions.

react_del¶

bool – Toggles whether atoms with the 'del' propety are deleted by react().

bonded_fgs(macro_mol)¶

An iterator which yields ids of functional groups to be bonded.

The ids of functional groups in macro_mol are assigned by place_mols(). The ids are stored as atom properties under the name 'fg_id', This method looks at the macromolecule and determines which functional groups should be bonded to create the final macromolecule. It then yields the ids functional groups as a tuple.

This tuple gets passed to react().

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Raises:NotImplementedError
build(macro_mol, bb_conformers=None)¶

Assembles rdkit instances of macromolecules.

This method places an rdkit molecule of the assembled macromolecule into the mol attribute of MacroMolecule. It also updates the MacroMolecule.bb_counter and MacroMolecule.bonds_made attributes.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The MacroMolecule instance which needs to be built.
  • bb_conformers (list of int, optional) – The ids of the building block conformers to be used. Must be equal in length to building_blocks and orders must correspond. If None, then -1 is used for all building blocks.
Returns:

None
Return type:

NoneType
cleanup(macro_mol)¶

Performs final clean up actions on an assembled molecule.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
place_mols(macro_mol)¶

Places building blocks.

The rdkit molecules of the building blocks are combined into a single rdkit molecule and placed into macro_mol.mol. Beyond this, the function must give every functional group in the macromolecule a unique id. This is done by adding the property 'fg_id' to every atom part of a functional group in macro_mol. Atoms in the same functional group will have the same value of 'fg_id' while atoms in different functional groups will have a different 'fg_id'.

The function is also reponsible for updating bb_counter.

Finally, this function must also add the tags 'bb_index' and 'mol_index' to every atom in the molecule. The 'bb_index' tag identifies which building block the atom belongs to. The building block is identified by its index within MacroMolecule.building_blocks. The 'mol_index' identifies which molecule of a specific building the atom belongs to. For example, if bb_index = 1 and mol_index = 3 the atom belongs to the 4th molecule of macro_mol.building_blocks[1] to be added to the macromolecule. The utility function add_fragment_props() is provided to help with this.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Raises:NotImplementedError
prepare(macro_mol)¶

Performs ops between placing and reacting building blocks.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
update_fg_id(macro_mol, mol)¶
class stk.molecular.topologies.base.TopologyMeta¶

Bases: type

Makes a repr of an instance, based initialization arguments used.

stk.molecular.topologies.base.remove_confs(building_blocks, keep)¶

Removes all conformers from building_blocks except keep.

All kept conformers have their id set to 0.

Parameters:
  • building_blocks (iterable of StructUnit) – A set of StructUnit instances which represent the building blocks forming a macromolecule.
  • keep (list of int) – The ids of the building block conformers to be used for assembling the MacroMolecule. Must be equal in length to building_blocks and orders must correspond.
Returns:

A list of the form,

returned = [[conf1, conf2, conf3],
            [conf4, conf5],
            [conf6, conf7, conf8, conf9]]

where each sublist holds all the original conformers of a particular building block.
Return type:

list
